awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nonparametric Eigenanalysis of High Dimensional Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project contains a specific research agenda that aims at a general understanding of high dimensional nonparametric eigenanalysis through three fundamental and complementary directions: (1) regularized estimation and variable selection, (2) statistical inference of eigenstructure, including hypothesis testing and confidence statements, and (3) minimax rates and complexity theoretic limits. The first direction will offer flexible regularization and variable selection of eigenstructure through regression based techniques, regularized power methods and other efficient algorithms. The second direction will lead to valid nonparametric testing procedures and confidence sets for eigenstructure with intrinsic sparsity. The third direction will characterize the fundamental limits of inferential accuracy in high dimensional eigenanalysis and its difference from what can be achieved by computationally efficient algorithms. The research will bring in new perspectives from other disciplines such as convex geometry, information theory and theoretical computer science to break new ground in high dimensional statistics. An effort will be made to seek out collaborations with scientists in topics that are related to the methodological and theoretical work.

Advances in science and technology have generated datasets of increasingly high dimensionality in many fields such as medical imaging, climate studies, and bioinformatics. When processing data arising in these applications, eigenanalysis of certain matrix objects, such as the covariance matrix, plays a central role in summarizing and unveiling the underlying structure of data, which often has intrinsic sparsity. This research project spans multiple directions, each aiming at advancing the methodological development and the theoretical understanding of high dimensional eigenanalysis from a different fundamental aspect. Upon completion, it will lead to a comprehensive general understanding of high dimensional eigenanalysis that will significantly enhance the ability to employ it in a wide range of scientific settings. The methodological development will be disseminated to the broader scientific community through user-friendly software packages that will serve as the basis for potential applications. The research output will also be effectively integrated with educational activities such as course development and mentoring at both undergraduate and graduate levels.

por.por_cntn:
During the period of this award, the PI has worked with Ph.D. students and collaborators on developing theory and methods for eigenanalysis in high-dimensional statistics and in network data analysis.

The PI has published more than 10 journal papers during this period with acknowledgment of support from this grant, including 5 in the Annals of Statistics, 4 in the Journal of Machine Learning Research, and 1 in the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. Two additional manuscripts on research supported by the grant have been accepted by the Annals of Statistics recently and are in the publication process. In addition, the PI presented 24 invited talks in department colloquia/seminars and international and domestic conferences and workshops on research supported by the NSF grant. Some of the highly cited papers published under the support of this grant include: 

Ma, Z. and Wu, Y. (2015). "Computational barriers in minimax submatrix detection". The Annals of Statistics, 43(3), 1089-1116.

Cai, T.T., Li, X. and Ma, Z. (2016). "Optimal rates of convergence for noisy sparse phase retrieval". The Annals of Statistics, 44(5), 2221-2251. 

Gao, C., Ma, Z., Zhang, Y. and Zhou, H.H. (2017). "Achieving optimal misclassification proportion in Stochastic Block Model". Journal of Machine Learning Research, 18(60), 1-49.

Gao, C., Ma, Z. and Zhou, H.H. (2017). "Sparse CCA: Adaptive estimation and computational barriers". The Annals of Statistics, 45(5), 2074-2101. 

Gao, C., Ma, Z., Zhang, Y. and Zhou, H.H. (2018). "Community detection in degree-corrected block models". The Annals of Statistics, 46(5), 2153?2185.

Under the grant support, the PI has developed a statistical optimality theory for the detection and the estimation of (generalized) eigen-structures in high dimensional settings. Guided by theory, he and his collaborators have also developed adaptive and computationally feasible algorithms that can be shown to achieve statistical optimal performances. He has also studied the statistical and computational tradeoffs in such problems. Algorithms developed in the project have been archived on the PI's webiste and made freely available to the broader community.

The methods developed by the PI have broad applications in medical and psychological research. They provide ready-to-use tools for researchers in these fields to analyze and to integrate high dimensional data. Some of the results have been incorporated into the Ph.D. course "Multivariate Statistics" that the PI teaches regularly. Four Ph.D. students have been supported partially by the grant.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2021
Modified by: Zongming Ma
